The public school, which has stood for nearly 90 years, continues to inspire a future in today’s youth while evoking nostalgia among older residents. There are few churches, mostly empty, yet the basketball courts remain busy. Every home looks different, but they share a similar feel. There’s a large supermarket called Super A, owned by a Yemeni family, possibly the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of residents are African American. The streets are wide, and kids often play football, pausing only for passing cars. Many of the neighborhood's residents have lived here for generations, each with stories of a past where everyone knew each other. There was a karate school, but when Hollywood stopped producing Karate Kid movies, the kids lost interest, and it became a pharmacy—since, supposedly, drugs solve everything. There's also a small movie theater showing classic films at a discount, avoiding crowds due to the youth's disdain for its lack of new releases, but appreciated by the elders who enjoy a night out at an affordable price, without the kids, of course. A single expressway runs through my town, though the entrance and exit are in the neighboring town. There was once a petition for an exit in our town, supported by the youth but opposed by the elders, who believed an expressway would ruin it. The elders eventually convinced the city council to deny the request. A new high school is being built, and we're trying to choose a mascot. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would best represent my town.

Living in a large city means my neighborhood is highly diverse. Residential areas are scattered among commercial zones, where different businesses operate. Some of these businesses are offices, while others include various shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There is always a new restaurant to try or a shop to visit. Some stores are large, well-known chains owned by big corporations, but small boutiques are becoming increasingly popular too. These boutiques are not only found in malls but also line the streets, often within walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be peaceful if not for the numerous attractions nearby. There are also a couple of parks close by, which are popular with families and their young children. As for the residents, my neighborhood is quite diverse. In a small area, we have a notable LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and groups of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Beyond my immediate neighborhood, the city is home to people of various races and backgrounds, often residing in their own distinct communities. We have areas such as Korea Town, China Town, and Little Armenia, just a few miles away. However, even a short distance can take a long time to drive due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Few people walk anywhere in my city, despite some attractions being nearby, as the city is vast and walking isn’t the preferred mode of travel. Consequently, we have some of the worst traffic globally, and finding parking is challenging almost everywhere. Ironically, there has been a lot of construction recently, with new apartment buildings rising in the city. It seems to be a popular place, but many residents are unhappy about the prospect of more people and vehicles. There are various types of housing in my city. Not everyone lives or wants to live in large apartment complexes. Residential areas feature houses of different sizes, along with smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties have single-family homes, while others have duplexes, even within my immediate neighborhood, so housing diversity is also present. Similarly, the neighborhood consists of people of different ages, and honestly, I don’t know most of my neighbors. It isn’t a close-knit community nowadays, though I have fond childhood memories of playing outside with my next-door neighbor and a few other friends of similar age from the neighborhood.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we drove past cornfields stretching to the horizon. "This is it!" I replied, anticipating her surprise at the vast openness. She came from a town where the grocery store was only a five-minute walk from her home; she'd never experienced such open space before. As she absorbed the endless cornfields, I explained what it was like growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she understood who I was and where I came from. Driving down the two-lane country road, you’ll come across a quarry filled with water. Just beyond it lies the small development where I live. The houses here are mostly made of brick and stucco, each sitting on at least half an acre, which residents take pride in maintaining. In spring, the area is alive with newly planted flowers and the midwestern trees that change with the seasons. Driveways showcase high-end Mercedes Benz luxury cars, sparkling in the midday sun after a thorough car wash. As we approach my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a welcoming smile. He spends his day mowing the lawn and can often be heard singing over the hum of his mower. Everyone in the neighborhood enjoys his presence; he is genuine and has a remarkable past. Though age has dulled some of his sharpness, he was once a doctor and often blends into the grass with his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Finally, you arrive at my house. In the side yard, geese are often chased by our Terrier. At the back, a small stream flows into the quarry, where you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional "moo" from nearby farms. Across a handmade wooden bridge lies an untouched haven filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This was where I spent most of my childhood, building tree forts and 'hunting' animals, which mostly meant chasing them, always finding something to do and usually a neighborhood child to play with. Winters in my small town can be harsh yet stunning. The yard transforms from a lush green to a barren wilderness. Trees that once held vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers become bare skeletons of bark. When snow occasionally falls, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is decorated with snow angels made by my little sister and snowmen. My sister and I often quarreled as kids, and in winter, snowballs were our chosen weapons. We’d construct massive igloo-like forts to store our ammunition, using branches as an arsenal. In our little wonderland, we played pretend, back when nothing else mattered. We were just carefree children.
